headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: "Barbie" Hits Movie Theaters; Briana Scurry is Interviewed about the World Cup; Remembering Tony Bennett. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: ABBY PHILLIP, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I'm also a Delta. And so she is now technically my sorority sister.

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, at least she's got, you know, famous and important friends that she can hang out with.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I think so.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: You know, I -- that's - that's cool. That's really cool. I am not.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That's OK. Maybe you can (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I didn't rush. I didn't rush. I didn't rush. I don't think - don't think I - I can't - like the level of elite, I think, amongst that group, not me.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: All right. That's OK, OK, we still love you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Thank you for that.Well, here's also what's important in the world. Barbieheimer week -- Barbenheimer - Barbenheimer -

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Bar - Barben -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Barbenheimer. It's upon us.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: "Oppenheimer" and the "Barbie" movie in theaters today.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We will hear from the Barbie herself, Margot Robbie, and her co-star, America Ferrera, next.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) AMERICA FERRERA, ACTRESS, "BARBIE": The movie turns a lot of things on its head. And - and to -- in my opinion tells us more about us as humans. (END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It's a blockbuster holiday weekend. The highly anticipated movies "Oppenheimer" and "Barbie" are hitting theaters today.Our Sara Sidner sat down with two stars of the "Barbie" movie last month before, I should note, the actors went on strike, and she joins us now. So, Sara, a lot of people don't know this about Margot Robbie, but she played a really critical role in even getting this movie to be created in the first place. What did they tell you? SARA SIDNER, CNN ANCHOR, "CNN NEWS CENTRAL": Some interesting things. It's -- I asked them, I said, look, when I was a little girl, I didn't play with Barbie. I was too busy jumping out of trees and trying to be better than the -

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You were too cool for Barbie.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Well, no, I was just trying to be better than the boys all the time.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I was very competitive. And Margot Robbie jumps up and says, me, too! And then America Ferrera says, I didn't play with Barbie either. And I was like, so what's with the movie? And both of them -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That's a great follow-up. I -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I mean both of them said, this movie has heart. It will make you laugh. But it might also make you cry. It's deep. "Barbie" is deep. That's what I learned.Take a listen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right, I'm going to start with you, Margot, everyone makes Barbie into who they think she is because she doesn't talk, she doesn't walk. So, we use our imaginations. How did you decide who Barbie was going to be in this film?MARGOT ROBBIE, ACTRESS, "BARBIE": To be honest, Gretta knew from the beginning really that she wanted Barbie to have the classic hero's journey. She actually used like buddha's journey to enlightenment as a reference. And I was like, OK, wow, I didn't see that coming but now that you've said it, it does make perfect sense. And so -- so suddenly she did have like this framework of a narrative. And within that we could have all these conversations on so many different levels. And - and what we wanted to do about with those conversations is kind of honor the legacy that the 64 years of Barbie has, you know, created, you know, and also bring it into today's day. You know how about -- have culturally relevant conversations.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: OK, I do have to ask, America, how deliciously ironic is it that Ryan Gosling's age became the thing that people were talking about, not the woman, but the man for once?AMERICA FERRERA, ACTRESS, "BARBIE": Oh, yes, that's -

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: It is ironic.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: Yes. I just heard that that's a thing.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: You know, that's the - that's the fate of the Kens in Barbie land is they essentially have to suffer a lot of the fate of women in the real world.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: And -- and, you know, it - it - it - it kind of highlights its stupidity, really. But - but it's, you know, the movie turns a lot of things on its head. And - and to -- in my opinion, tells us more about us as humans than - than really, you know, a move about dolls.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And, America, you play one of the few characters who is not a doll, who is not a Barbie in the movie. You're a real-life person going through real-life challenges as a working woman. What happens when you and Barbie meet finally?

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: I don't want to spoil anything, but it's -

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: We (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh, don't spoil it. Give us -

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: We're just friends (ph).

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: The moment that Gloria and Barbie connect, I just started, like, bawling. And - and it felt so beautiful that, you know, a grown woman could explore her imagination and her playfulness and - and really be enthusiastic about something that she loved and something that was playful and inspiring to her and that that didn't have to be in contradiction to her as like a grown, serious, professional woman.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I have to be honest though, I was not a Barbie obsessed girl. I was too busy jumping out of trees and racing boys and trying to be better than the boys.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: I was exactly like you.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Did you all play with Barbies? OK.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: I was not a Barbie - I was not a Barbie girl. Were you? You -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: OK. ROBBIE

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Nope.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: And she was like, no, I couldn't even get you to wear a dress. I was like, oh.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: I mean, a, like, we couldn't afford Barbies. B, like, I don't know, it's just like didn't -- the world of Barbie didn't feel like it had very much for me in it to be perfectly honest. But that is what is so beautiful to me about this moment and getting to be a part of this story that is expanding the world of Barbie to include the rest of us. And what I think the movie gives us is the permission to be more of who we are. That, like, Barbie gets to be - that we're all Barbie and Barbie gets to be whatever the hell Barbie wants to be.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Margot, what are you hoping to impart to the audience with this film?

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: The feeling of, like, yes, it's, like, you want to do this and you want to be a good mom and you want to be a good friend and you want to be a good husband and you want to be an ally and you want to be an activist but you want to just do your job and you just want to get through the day and blah, blah, blah, blah, blah. If I could put all of that off your shoulders and just say, you're already doing great. You are doing great because you are you and that is enough. That's what I would give.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Yes. And it was so much fun. We had a Barbie sleepover. The Kens were invited to visit, not to stay over, obviously. We all wore our pajamas and ordered room service and we shared beds -

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: It's true (ph).

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: And we played games and we all discovered how incredibly competitive America is when it comes to games.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about how Ryan (ph) sent a man in a kilt to play bagpipes at us for three minutes and then recite the speech from "Braveheart."

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: "Braveheart." FERRERA

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: It was (INAUDIBLE) -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Just -- it was just amazing. And if that doesn't bond you, I don't know what will.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: I still - I still don't get the joke. Was it an inside joke?

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: No. No. It was no relation -

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: No, it wasn't? There was no inside joke?

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: There was no "Braveheart" connection at all.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Was he trying to say, like, freedom? Like, what - he must have been trying to say something.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: It was like -

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: You'll have to ask Ryan, I guess.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: I feel like he was rallying us.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: He was - it was -

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: Because it was right before we were starting, right?

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: It was like a -

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: He was like, here we go.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Yes, a rallying war cry perhaps, yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Ladies, I - I actually was, like, oh, am I going to see the "Barbie" - but the way you've described it, it's like something I think that girlfriends could go to together and buddies could go together with the kids and just enjoy the ride.

utterances.speaker: FERRERA
utterances.sentences: Oh, (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. It's a party and everyone is invited.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right, spoiler alert. Here is a lesson you will learn from this movie because I may or may not have seen it. Being human is hard. Being a female human is even harder. But it's worth it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That's a great moral of the story.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That's my zen for the morning.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes. SIDNER

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: So, I have a theory about the bagpipes, because I had heard that story before.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Maybe it was like a primal male scream, like they weren't -- the Kens were not allowed at the sleepover, so they really just had like the "Braveheart" thing. That's my theory.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That - that actually - that - that fits. That completely and utterly fits.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I mean, can I weigh in here or am I going to be excluded?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I was going to say, nobody's talking just to Ken - I mean, Phil.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. Why, yes, Ken.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes. Like, it's - no, I don't -

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Do tell us, Ken.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Time out. Stop.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What you think.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: What I will say is, like, that - that move from a, like, leadership perspective to me is, like, oh, yes, that's totally dope. And then like I hear them describe it and I was like, oh, wow, that's super weird.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) may or may not.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Don't do that. That's not cool.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That's not cool.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Regardless of audience, but particularly with that audience.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I do need to remind people, this is a Warner Bros. Discovery program.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That's true. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: We -- we are also owned by Warner Bros. Discovery. But -- and they did this, obviously, before the strike, because this is not -- you - you're not allowed to sort of promote things. So, that's where we are. I enjoyed it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That being said, we love your Barbie pink.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Thank you for gracing us with your presence.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh, wait. I come from Barbie world.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was going to say, I'm like, we were all pausing and waiting so we could get -- there we go.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: A Barbie cake pop.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That's good.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We need this.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: This is happiness. This is happiness from Sara Sidner.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Sara.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Thanks, buddy.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, there is another important film that's coming out despite Sara's focus on only one of them. Most blockbusters, when it comes to this film, they use a lot of CGI. In fact, you talk about another big release this summer, the new "Indiana Jones" movie, created a computer generated Harrison Ford de-aged to make the 81- year-old actor look 40 years younger. And in the new "Mission Impossible" movie, this stunt is definitely real, but the ramp Tom Cruise used to fly off of this cliff was painted out of look-alike grass and gravel. But in "Oppenheimer," Christopher Nolan told "The Hollywood Reporter" there are no CGI shots, and that includes a scene depicting the first ever test explosion of the nuclear bomb.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER NOLAN
utterances.sentences: We wanted imagery that has beauty but threat to it. (INAUDIBLE) graphics tend to be - they can feel a bit anadime (ph), a bit safe. That's why they're tough to use in horror movies, for example. But finding -- challenging my team to use real methods, some of them microscopic and tiny, some of them absolutely vast, that, I think, gives the imagery the bite that it needs.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: It's worth noting, this isn't new for Nolan. He's made a career of using practical effects in his movies whenever he can. In one of the most iconic moments of "The Dark Knight," Nolan flips a semi-truck end over end for this scene. And later in the movie, he did this.(VIDEO CLIP) MATTINGLY: Now, again, both the truck flip and this hospital explosion were done using practical effects, not computer generated at all. For the final installment of his "Batman" trilogy, the external shots of this opening airplane sequence were shot practically, including this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Calm down, doctor. Now is not the time for fear. That comes later.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And in 2010's "Inception," Nolan built a real-life rotating hallway for this dream within a dream fight scene.(VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: In the movie "Interstellar," to get the effect of an ice- covered planet, Nolan filmed these scenes on this melting glacier in Iceland.And in this most recent movie, "Tenant," Nolan crashed a real 747, insisting it was, quote, more efficient than using CGI. (VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: This is all completely fascinating. A little bit different than "Barbie." Moviegoers will be able to get the chance to see "Oppenheimer" and its total and complete lack of CGI today.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That's super interesting, Phil. Thank you for that.And up next for us, the U.S. Women's -- take the field tonight in the -- as they begin their quest to be the first country to win three World Cups in a row, men or women. Our next guest knows a thing or two about winning the World Cup. The legendary Briana Scurry will joins us, next. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And welcome back.In just a few hours the U.S. National Soccer Team, the women's team, is set to make their appearance at the World Cup. And joining us now on that is former goal keeper for the U.S. team, Briana Scurry. It was her save during the penalty kicks that helped the team win the World Cup back in 1999. She is also a two-time Olympic gold medalist. Briana, thank you for joining us. There's so much pressure, as I'm sure you know, on this team today, and right now, to become the first to win three World Cups in a row. How important is this first game for them in setting the tone? BRIANA SCURRY, TWO-TIME OLYMPIC GOLD MEDAL U.S. AND WORLD CUP SOCCER CHAMP: The first game is absolutely critical. It sets the tone, like you said. You want to come into that first game and literally blow the doors off the opponent and also make a statement in your group and throughout the tournament that shows that the USA is ready to go. Vlatko normally has a little bit of rotation in his starting lineup. So, todays starting 11 may not be the same as the starting 11 against the Netherlands. But today's game is absolutely critical.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: For folks who are familiar, I think, you know, there's still a number of the top veterans that are on this team that everybody will know, but there's also just a core group of younger players, don't have certainly a lot of, I think, public attention before now, if you're not in kind of this -- the world or the scene but are hugely talented. Who should they be watching?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: All right, Briana Scurry, we will all be watching tonight as the U.S. women's team hits the grass on the field. Thank you for joining us.

utterances.speaker: SCURRY
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: This is CNN breaking news.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And we have breaking news, sad breaking news. This morning, music icon Tony Bennett has died at the age of 96.Chloe Melas joins us now. And, Chloe, legend feels like an understatement to some degree when you talk about Tony Bennett. What more can you tell us?

utterances.speaker: CHLOE MELAS, CNN ENTERTAINMENT REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, incredibly sad news for people all over the world this morning. Tony Bennett has died at the age of 96. His publicist, Sylvia Weiner, his long-time publicist, confirming this morning. And, you know, this comes as a shock to many. He lived a long,beautiful life. I had the honor of meeting him when he turned 90 and performed in New York at the Rainbow Room. We don't know the circumstances of his death, but we know that he had been battling Alzheimer's for the past several years. His wife, Susan Bennett, she actually told "AARP Magazine" in 2021 that despite the Alzheimer's, he was continuing to perform, put out music. You know, obviously, we know that he toured and put out albums with Lady Gaga. I've reached out to her and I'm sure that this is obviously a devastating loss for her. They were just so close. But his career spanned decades from the early 1950s. And Frank Sinatra is someone who touted him as one of the greatest voices of a generation. And so I, you know, meeting Tony Bennett, there's just nothing like - like it. And he was so charismatic, so kind and just, obviously, so talented. And so it's a very sad day for everyone who had the pleasure of meeting him, knowing him or just loving his music to know that he has passed at his home in New York at the age of 96.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Anderson, CNN has now confirmed that Tony Bennett has died. We're expecting a statement shortly.That "60 Minutes" piece that you did, Anderson, was so incredibly poignant. And I remember when, you know, Lady Gaga was kind of describing -- it was almost like a switch flipped, and then you demonstrated it. But you also made a great point, the life lived - we've only got about a minute and a half left -- civil rights in particular, obviously his military service. Can you capture what - what he was, not just those last performances, but just overall?
